8.title: Joyce Adamson Obituary March 8, 2025
8.snippet: Joyce Adamson, age 80, of Brooksby Village in Peabody, formerly of Stoneham, passed away on Saturday March 8 at Salem Hospital. She was born in Brooklyn,...
8.content:
Joyce Adamson, age 80, of Brooksby Village in Peabody, formerly of Stoneham, passed away on Saturday March 8 at Salem Hospital. She was born in Brooklyn, NY and was the daughter of Robert and Muriel (Aust) Roberts.

Joyce grew up in Brooklyn and Valley Stream, NY, graduated from Brandeis University and Boston University Medical School. She was a loving and beloved doctor in Stoneham for more than 25 years, was Chair of the Department of Medicine at Winchester Hospital and served on the Stoneham Board of Health. Always active in the community, she was a longtime member of the Unitarian Universalist Church of Reading and supported refugee resettlement and other charitable works. She was the proud mother of Glenn Adamson of Highland, NY and London, UK, and Peter Adamson of Munich, Germany.

In 2002 Joyce was disabled by illness and for more than twenty years lived with her husband David Adamson, under his care. She is also survived by her granddaughters Sophia and Johanna.

Her Memorial Service will be held at the Unitarian Universalist Church, 239 Woburn St., Reading on Friday April 11 at 10am. For guestbook, visit McDonald-Finnegan-Anderson Funeral Home at www.mcdonaldfs.com.

9.title: 5 McDonald's 'Eat This, Not That' Picks and 5 You Should Skip
9.snippet: Here are 5 McDonald's menu swaps for better nutrition, from breakfast to burgers and dessert.
9.content:
If you're craving McDonalds but want to stick to somewhat healthier options, certain menu items can help hit the spot without completely derailing your health and fitness progress. Many items are high-calorie but also contain a surprisingly impressive amount of protein, and while dessert items are understandably higher in sugar, there isn't a ton of sugar randomly added to other sandwiches, fries, and nuggets. So what should you choose to have as a treat, without having to feel not-great afterwards? Here are 5 items to eat and 5 to avoid at McDonald's, based on nutrition.

Eat This: Egg McMuffin, Not That: Hotcakes

McDonald's has an excellent breakfast menu, but the health benefits of items differ wildly. One of the best choices for a nutritious start to the day is the Egg McMuffin, which is just 310 calories, contains 17g of protein, and just 3g of sugar. You also get all the nutrients of a whole, freshly-cracked egg, and lean meat. In comparison, the McDonald's Hotcakes are 580 calories, 45g of sugar, and just 9g of protein. There's no question which one is better for you (and frankly more delicious).

Eat This: Quarter Pounder with Cheese, Not That: Double BBQ Bacon Quarter Pounder with Cheese

Sometimes only a really good, juicy burger will hit the spot, and luckily you can get that on the McDonald's menu without going overboard with calories and sugar. The Quarter Pounder with Cheese has 520 calories, a very decent 30g of protein, and 10g of sugar for what's quite a filling sandwich. On the other hand, the Double BBQ Bacon Quarter Pounder with Cheese is impressive protein-wise, containing 54g of protein, but it also has 850 calories and 12g of sugar. It also has 54g of fat vs the Quarter Pounder with Cheese's 26g of fat.6254a4d1642c605c54bf1cab17d50f1e

McDonald's New Menu Item Features Today's Biggest Basketball Stars

Eat This: Chicken McNuggets, Not That: French Fries

What's your favorite side: Nuggets or fries? A 6-piece serving of McDonald's Chicken McNuggets contains 250 calories, zero sugar, and 14g of protein. Compare that to a small serving of McDonald's French Fries which contains 230 calories, 3g of protein, but also zero sugar. The McNuggets clearly have the edge nutrition-wise but McDonald's fries are famous for good reason.

Eat This: Vanilla Cone, Not That: Vanilla Shake

McDonald's sweet treats are iconic, from Shamrock Shakes to Oreo McFlurries. The McDonald's soft serve Vanilla Cone is 200 calories, 5g of protein, and 23g of sugar, making it a perfectly reasonable dessert. On the other hand the small Vanilla Shake is 480 calories, with 10g of protein and 51g of sugar. The Vanilla Cone is clearly the way to go, sweet enough without going overboard.

Eat This: McCrispy, Not That: McChicken

What if you want a chicken sandwich? The McCrispy is 470 calories, contains 26g of protein, and 9g of sugar. Meanwhile the McChicken is 390 calories, with 14g of protein and 4g of sugar. The McCrispy has 20g of fat and the McChicken has 21, but overall the McCrispy offers a better protein amount and will probably keep you feeling full for longer. However, if calories are more of a concern than macronutrients, the McChicken is the way to go.

0.title: Cheryl Ann Hurley Obituary September 30, 1958
0.snippet: Cheryl Ann Hurley, age 66 of Wakefield, passed away on Friday, March 7 at the Lahey Medical Center in Burlington surrounded by her loving family.
0.content:
Cheryl Ann Hurley, age 66 of Wakefield, passed away on Friday, March 7 at the Lahey Medical Center in Burlington surrounded by her loving family.

She was born in Melrose on September 30, 1958 and was the daughter of the late Richard and Claire (Cassidy) Stevens.

She was the beloved wife of James Hurley of Wakefield for 46 years. She was the loving mother of James Hurley Jr. of Wakefield, and John Hurley and his wife Sarah of Wakefield, and the late Shauna Hurley. She was the sister of Mary Ellen Kelloway and her husband Lenny of Lynn, Linda Makarewicz and her late husband Kenny of Wakefield, Richie Stevens of Wakefield, Kathy Garofano and her husband Kevin of Exeter, NH, and Carolyn Tucker and her husband Marty of Middleton. Cheryl was also the cherished grandmother of Jack, Jameson, Aaron, and Lily. She is also survived by many loving nieces and nephews.

Cheryl was a devoted wife and mother whose greatest joy came from spending time with loved ones and hosting holiday gatherings. A devout Catholic, her faith guided her life and inspired her selflessness, as she always opened her home to those in need, providing a safe haven for friends and family during challenging times. She cherished motorcycle rides with her husband and enjoyed cozy evenings watching Hallmark Channel movies together. Cheryl looked forward to her annual girls' weekend with her sisters on Plum Island, where laughter and bonding flourished. She loved skiing at Ragged Mountain, often retreating to her mother’s house for cozy family moments. As a school room mother, she took pride in nurturing the next generation, and her enthusiasm shone brightly during the Wakefield 4th of July parades. Cheryl's adventurous spirit was also evident in her love for camping trips along the scenic Kangamangus River and attending country music concerts, where she felt the magic of live music. Above all, she treasured quality time with her grandkids, creating lasting memories that will be cherished forever. Her legacy of joy, love, and connection will always be remembered.

Visitation for relatives and friends will be held at the McDonald Funeral Home, 19 Yale Ave., Wakefield on Wednesday March 12 from 4:00 – 7:00 p.m. Her Funeral Mass will be celebrated in St. Joseph Church, 173 Albion St., Wakefield on Thursday March 13 at 10:00 a.m. Interment, Forest Glade Cemetery, Wakefield.

1.title: ROGER E. McDONALD
1.snippet: Roger E. McDonald, affectionately known to many as “Reggie,” passed away with his family by his side on March 3, 2025, at My Michigan Medical Center in...
1.content:
May 22, 1946 – March 3, 2025

Roger E. McDonald, affectionately known to many as “Reggie,” passed away with his family by his side on March 3, 2025, at My Michigan Medical Center in Alpena, Michigan, leaving behind a legacy of laughter, kindness, and cherished memories. Born on May 22, 1946, in Alpena, Roger was the beloved son of the late Delmar and Bertha (Schiler) McDonald.

After dedicating 37 years of his life to Abitibi as a press operator, Roger embraced retirement with the same vigor he applied to his career. He approached every day with a joyful spirit, often brightening up the room with his infectious laugh and quick wit. It is said that he took great joy in being called Roscoe P. Coultrane, a nickname that truly captured his lively essence.

Throughout his life, Roger took pride in serving his country in the United States Navy, wearing his service with honor. His passions extended far beyond his professional endeavors; he cherished playing softball in his younger years, enjoyed the challenge of crossword puzzles, and relished the thrill of all sports. Neighbors often smiled as they witnessed him mowing his lawn or tending to those nearby–his trusty riding lawnmower became a symbol of his caring nature and willingness to lend a hand. No season was complete without Roger feeding the birds and deer, finding joy in the simplicity of connecting with nature.

Roger is survived by his two sons, Curt (Tammie) McDonald and Douglas (Tabitha) McDonald, who carry forward his spirit through the love and lessons he imparted, He was the best Dad anyone could ask for. He was a proud grandfather, leaving behind seven grandchildren and thirteen great-grandchildren. His sister Winifred remains a cherished part of his family, reminding them of the bonds that transcend time.

Roger’s kind nature earned him the title of the best father-in-law in the world, an esteemed accomplishment he held close to his heart. He touched the lives of many with his warmth and caring demeanor, and his passing leaves an irreplaceable void. Those who knew him will fondly remember the smile that lit up his face and the joy that followed him wherever he went.

Roger is preceded in death by his parents, Delmar and Bertha, along with his siblings Fran, Virginia, and Harland. As a kind, caring, and fun-loving man, Roger E. McDonald will be dearly missed by all whose lives he touched. A private family memorial service will be held at a later date, honoring the remarkable life of a man who brought so much joy to those around him.

2.title: ‘We have a jury’: 18 selected for Megan McDonald murder trial
2.snippet: A jury for the trial of Edward Holley, accused of murdering Megan McDonald, was chosen after a weeklong process that began with a pool of over 400...
2.content:
At far right, Edward Holley and his legal defense team, which includes Eli Siems, center right, Paul Weber, center left, and Chris Sevier, have a discussion before jury candidates are brought into Orange County Court Judge Hyun Chin Kim's courtroom in Goshen on March 6. The jury selection process for Holley's trial lasted four days. Lana Bellamy/Times Union

GOSHEN — “We have a jury,” Orange County Court Judge Hyun Chin Kim announced Thursday, ending a long first week in the most high-profile murder case in Orange County’s recent history.

The group of 18 includes six alternates. They will spend the next five weeks hearing the case investigators built against Edward Holley, the 44-year-old Wawayanda man accused of murdering Megan McDonald in 2003. They were selected from a pool of nearly 400 Orange County residents chosen at random to report for jury selection.

Advertisement Article continues below this ad

The panel is overwhelmingly female — 13 are women — but they represent a range of ages, races and professional backgrounds. A female teaching assistant and former lieutenant for the New York City Fire Department. A man who lives in Port Jervis, has four kids and enjoys kickboxing. A researcher at a world-renowned cancer center whose favorite movie is “Good Will Hunting.” A New Windsor man who is a supervisor at a retail chain distribution center.

Some hold master’s degrees; others have a high-school-level education. One woman spent decades counseling residents at a local homeless shelter. “I do a lot of listening,” she told attorneys. Another juror worked as a flagman for an electrical union.

Their personalities appear varied, too, from quiet and contemplative to bold and outspoken.

One juror, a self-employed woman, told the attorneys she believes “there are three sides to every story.” She served on a criminal trial jury that reached a verdict in Rockland County over a decade ago.

Advertisement Article continues below this ad

Holley is charged with second-degree murder in connection with the killing of McDonald, a friend with whom he had a prior romantic relationship. Holley had been a suspect in the investigation that spanned two decades, but State Police did not charge him until April 20, 2023. He was indicted by a grand jury nine months later — a process that was drawn out after the Orange County district attorney recused himself and special prosecutors were appointed. The indictment alleges he did not act alone. Holley has maintained his innocence in several police interviews over the years.

The prosecution has a list of 80 witnesses they may call during the trial. The defense has listed more than 30 potential witnesses. Judge Kim expects the trial to last through April 11.

Jury selection began on the morning of March 3. Each round started with Kim asking a subgroup of jurors about their associations with prosecutors, Holley’s lawyers, witnesses, exposure to media coverage of the case, and other general questions that assessed their ability to serve. Then Kim moved to one-on-one interviews with some jurors in hourslong closed sessions. Most were eliminated during that process.

Whoever was left became part of voir dire, a final step in deciding who sits on the jury. During this stage, attorneys learn more about each candidate, including what they like to do in their spare time, where they work and if they have prior jury experience. They also ask about their abilities to be open-minded and fair.

Advertisement Article continues below this ad

The Murder of Megan McDonald newsletter Stay up to date with the latest updates in the 2003 case and the upcoming trial of Edward V. Holley. Sign up here.

‘Are you up for this?’

The lawyers went through a handful of voir dire rounds with 20 to 26 candidates at a time. Each attorney took a slightly different approach.

On Wednesday, one of Holley’s defense attorneys, Chris Sevier, began with a serious question: “Are you up for this? That’s a question I want you to ask yourselves.”

Advertisement Article continues below this ad

He apparently tried to test the candidates’ ability to judge testimony using a hypothetical trial about financial theft, but after being stopped by the judge, he had to move on. So, he polled them on their favorite books, movies and TV shows. The questioning brought up moments of levity as jurors and Sevier went back and forth about their favorite ways to be entertained. But in the end, he circled back to the seriousness of the moment.

The trial will be long, Sevier told them. It will be intense. It will not be fun. Their job will be difficult.

Special prosecutors Laura Murphy and Julia Cornachio employed a more conversational approach, peppering prospective jurors about their jobs, favorite authors and aspirations. Murphy asked two groups of jury candidates to promise not to hold prosecutors to a “greater burden” than they are tasked with.

All the attorneys reminded the candidates that they must only make decisions based on what they learn in the courtroom. Judge Kim also reminded jurors of the roles of each party. The defense doesn’t have to prove anything; Holley is presumed innocent unless the prosecution can prove he is guilty.

Advertisement Article continues below this ad

On Thursday evening, defense attorney Eli Siems used the Socratic method to address the pool, asking what they should do if something at trial reminds them of a news story they read. A volunteer at the Newburgh Armory Unity Center said she would notify the judge and attorneys. Before Siems could comment on her answer, a retired EMT next to her jumped in. They should push it aside, she said, because it wasn’t something they learned inside the courtroom.

The former EMT was chosen as a juror in the final round.

The jurors will report back to court Monday morning to hear each party’s opening statements.

3.title: McDonald's Stock Hits All-Time High Friday
3.snippet: McDonald's shares hit an intraday record high Friday, continuing their unsteady climb since an E. coli outbreak last October.
3.content:
McDonald's (MCD) shares hit an intraday record high Friday, continuing their unsteady climb since an E. coli outbreak last October.

McDonald's shares rose about 4% in recent trading to $323.16, surpassing the previous intraday high of $317.90 set on Oct. 21, the day before the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) said dozens of cases of E. coli infection had been reported across several states.

Shares of the fast-food giant fell to as low as $276.53 on Jan. 16, but have risen about 16% since. They climbed nearly 5% in a single session on Feb. 10, when the company reported global comparable sales returned to growth in the fourth quarter.

McDonald's was the top gainer in the Dow Jones Industrial Average early Friday afternoon.

5.title: Every McDonald's Dessert Ranked
5.snippet: Through the years, McDonald's desserts come and go. Gone are the hard, crunchy McDonaldland cookies that, in the very old days, came in a cardboard box with...
5.content:
Through the years, McDonald's desserts come and go. Gone are the hard, crunchy McDonaldland cookies that, in the very old days, came in a cardboard box with every Happy Meal. Times changed, and they began to be packaged in plastic — and then were dropped from Happy Meals altogether when McDonald's shifted to a "healthier" kid's meal in 2004. Other desserts we miss are the cinnamon donuts (available in the 1990s) and, of course, the fried apple pie. The current baked one is good (and we'll talk about it later), but it's not the same thing as that original crispy fried dessert with its sweet, gooey interior.

There are many other discontinued McDonald's desserts that people miss, but what can you find on the menu today when you need a sweet treat? We rounded up every dessert from cookies to pies to ice cream and ranked them from worst to best. Although we have to admit, even the desserts ranked towards the worse side of the list can really hit the spot when you have that certain craving. Of course, it's all subjective, and perhaps you disagree. Read on for our ranking of McDonald's sweets.

7.title: McDonald’s Pushes Apple Pay Out The Window
7.snippet: “Customers who want to use their new iPhone 6 or iPhone 6 Plus to pay will have to tell the drive-through cashier that they are paying with their phone. The...
7.content:
McDonald’s Chief Digital Officer Atif Rafiq was talking with a reporter last week about how “seamless” and easy McDonald’s will incorporate ApplePay, which makes sense given how the chain has been accepting contactless payments for years. (We didn’t say that they had accepted a lot of them.) But Ratiq chose to take it to the next level and argued that Apple Pay would be accepted at the chain drive-thru windows.

In a delightful story in Recode, the author pushed Rafiq for specifics after the executive “talked in generalities a bit.” He eventually pushed the exec to send a photograph of it might look like. That’s the image illustrating this story.

“Customers who want to use their new iPhone 6 or iPhone 6 Plus to pay will have to tell the drive-through cashier that they are paying with their phone. The cashier will then extend a portable payment terminal out toward the driver’s-side window,” the story said. “The driver then can place their finger on the phone’s fingerprint ID sensor and tap or wave their phone in front of the payment device just outside their window. Will people prefer paying that way to handing over cash or credit? That may depend on how prepared the window attendants are and whether they can keep the ‘fast’ in “fast food.”

A few thoughts. First, those terminals are not especially light, as evidenced by the employee in the photo having to hold it with both arms. Secondly, while holding it outside the window, it is fully exposed to the elements. What happens if it’s pouring rain or snowing heavily? Beyond being potentially damaged, that unit is going to get progressively heavier in that snowstorm. For that matter, customers will have to hold their iPhones out in the same weather elements and it’s not clear that that will be good for the phone.

The story said that McDonald’s has further plans for ApplePay. “Accepting Apple Pay is just one step in series of digital enhancements coming to McDonald’s locations, according to Rafiq. The company will place an Apple Pay button on a forthcoming app, Rafiq said, though he declined to reveal specifics of what the app will do. Since payments will be involved, it could be an order-ahead app, like the one the company is currently testing at select locations in Alabama and Georgia.”

0.title: Who are the key figures in the Megan McDonald murder case? Trial details, what to know
0.snippet: In Orange County Court, Edward Holley faces a second-degree murder charge in the 2003 death of Megan McDonald. These are some facts and key players as the...
0.content:
Who are the key figures in the Megan McDonald murder case? Trial details, what to know

Edward Holley is on trial for the murder of Megan McDonald, who was found beaten to death in 2003.

Holley was charged 20 years after McDonald's death, a cold case that captured the community in the region for decades.

In Orange County Court, the case against Holley will involve special prosecutors, an absent potential suspect who died long before Holley's arrest and testimony regarding how Megan McDonald died that night in March.

Here are some of the key figures in the case.

Megan McDonald

On March 15, 2003, 20-year-old Megan McDonald was found bludgeoned to death in a field off Bowser Road in the Town of Wallkill. She was the daughter of Betty Jo McDonald and Dennis McDonald, an NYPD detective who investigated the first World Trade Center bombing in 1993. He died of a heart attack in 2002.

McDonald was a graduate of John S. Burke Catholic High School in Goshen in 2000, and at the time of her death she was taking classes at SUNY Orange Community College, and waitressing at American Cafe restaurant in the Galleria at Crystal Run in the Town of Wallkill.

She had been Holley's girlfriend, but they were no longer a couple at the time of her death.

Fatal crash: Middletown man killed in head-on crash on Route 17 in Harriman

Edward Holley

McDonald's former boyfriend, Edward Holley, 44, of Wawayanda, has been charged with second-degree murder in her death. He has pleaded not guilty.

He has been confined to a wheelchair since a 2007 car crash. If convicted, he faces up to 25 years to life in state prison.

Andre Thurston

According to an internal report reviewed by the USA Today Network in 2024, New York State Police believed Andre Thurston was in the car where McDonald was murdered.

Thurston, who was represented by Orange County District Attorney David Hoovler when he was a defense attorney, was never charged in the case. He died in 2010.

David Hoovler

Now Orange County's district attorney, Hoovler's office is not prosecuting the case because of a past connection.

In 2008, while he was a defense attorney, Hoovler represented Thurston and sought a plea deal for him, according to the internal state police report reviewed by the USA Today Network.

Five days after Holley’s arrest, Hoovler informed the McDonald family he would recuse himself and his office and hand the case to a special prosecutor.

Special prosecutors

Instead of Hoovler's office, the case is being prosecuted by two special prosecutors, Julia B. Cornachio and Laura Murphy.

Cornachio is a long-time Westchester County prosecutor, while Murphy is a veteran of the Westchester DA's Cold Case bureau.

Defense attorneys

Attorney Paul Weber is leading Holley's defense team and is being assisted by Christopher Sevier and Eli Siems.

The defense has objected to the appointment of the special prosecutors, maintaining that because they are being paid up to $300 an hour, with no cap, they were financially motivated to continue prosecuting their client.

DOT study: NY may consider safety improvements at Rosendale intersection where pedestrian was killed

But Orange County Court Judge Hyun Chin Kim denied their objection and noted it had been raised rather late in the process.

The judge

Overseeing the trial is Orange County Court Judge Hyun Chin Kim.

Holley's defense lawyers have also made repeated motions for her to step down from the case, on the grounds that her principal law clerk, Karen Edelman-Reyes, worked in the Orange County District Attorney's office when McDonald's murder was being investigated.

But Kim said Edelman-Reyes had been screened from the McDonald case from the earliest days she was presiding over it, and she has denied all motions for her to step down.

Mike Randall covers breaking news for the Times Herald-Record and the Poughkeepsie Journal. Reach him at mrandall@th-record.com.

1.title: People Miss Old-School McDonald's After Viral Photo Of 2025 PlayPlace
1.snippet: A woman shared a recent photo from her local McDonald's “PlayPlace,” and people were aghast.
1.content:
I had my 6th birthday party at our local McDonald’s, and it was an absolute banger. We had burgers, fries, and even those old-school McDonald’s sheet cakes! There were party hats and an appearance from Ronald himself. After singing “Happy Birthday,” all the kids ran into the giant PlayPlace (my mom used to call them “fart tunnels”) and we’d play for hours.

There was a time in history when having your birthday party at McDonald’s was the be-all, end-all. Obviously, things with birthday parties have changed a bit in the last couple of decades, but it was a magical time.

I am not the only one who feels this way, and when one woman shared a recent photo from her local McDonald’s “PlayPlace,” people were aghast.

X user Nancy French wrote, “This is so heart breaking. I’m at a new McDonalds in Franklin, TN and look at their ‘play place’ for children. Two screens/two chairs.”

She shared this alongside a picture of just that... a dim annex of the fast food restaurant with two tiny screens in the corner and two tiny chairs. The words “PlayPlace” are painted on the wall alongside a Happy Meal box with giant, weird eyes.

“I hope that’s only temporary! We still have the play equipment at my local McD’s,” one user said.

Another said, “This ruined my day”

She updated the post later writing, “I went back in to make sure I didn’t miss something. There was this column thing that might be for getting kids to exercise. But I don’t think this is temporary. I think this is it.”

The video she shared shows the updated space with an apparatus known as a JumpPad tower, where four kids can take a spot and jump as much as they can to get their lights to the top of the tower.

After her video went viral, several X users began reminiscing about old-school McDonald’s.

“The shift in McDonald’s vibe from 90’s to today captures everything wrong with society,” one user wrote.

Another said, “Remember having birthday parties at McDonalds? And they had actual party planners on staff? They were fun times.”

One X user explained that this change might be due to the bigger overhaul McDonald’s restaurants have been going through. “That’s one of the new ones. They’ve reworked their entire design to reflect less employees and more screens. ‘Automated McDonalds’ bc employees are only cooking. There’s no playground. Just places to wait for pickup,” they said.

In her latest update, French shared an old photo of what the Franklin McDonald’s used to look like before a fire.

“Hey guys! This was the previous McDonald’s structure that had to be replaced due to fire. The new ‘kids play place’ I posted below is to replace this enormous kids area,” she wrote.

Is it liability issues? Cutting costs? Is it corporate feelings uneasy about the idea of moms finding hours of reprieve in these kinds of places for a $5 Happy Meal? In any case, this two-screen “play place” definitely seems like an overcorrection.

3.title: McDonald’s dethroned as world’s largest fast food chain by company with no restaurants in the US
3.snippet: McDonald's is no longer the largest restaurant chain in the world. Mixue Bingcheng is a Chinese bubble tea and ice cream chain with more than 45,000...
3.content:
McDonald’s is no longer the largest restaurant chain in the world.

Mixue Bingcheng is a Chinese bubble tea and ice cream chain with more than 45,000 restaurants worldwide as of September 2024, while the number of McDonald’s restaurants all over the world is around 41,800, according to Statista via Chowhound.

The Asia-based fast-food chain is known for selling soft-serve ice cream cones for one yuan (15 cents) and drinks ranging from between 2 to 8 yuan (30 cents to $1.20).

Despite its huge number of locations, 90 percent of them are in China. There are also outlets in Indonesia, Vietnam, and Malaysia. There isn’t a single location in the United States.

Mixue Bingcheng was founded in 1997 by Zhang Hongchao, and originally started out as a store selling shaved ice and cold drinks.

“Let people around the world eat well and drink well for just two American dollars,” Hongchao previously told Chinese state media about his strategy for the business.

Mixue Bingcheng has over 45,000 restaurants worldwide, while McDonald’s has around 41,800 (Getty Images)

Over 99 percent of the bubble tea chain’s stores are franchised, with most of their revenue coming from selling food materials, equipment, and packaging to its franchisees.

Although Mixue Bingcheng does have the highest number of locations worldwide, its revenue is still behind other large drink chains in the U.S., such as Starbucks and Tim Hortons.

Its growth is rapid, though. According to its prospectus, Mixue’s net profit jumped 42 percent to 3.49 billion yuan ($479 million) in the first nine months of 2024 from the same period in the previous year. Its revenue increased 21 percent to 18.7 billion yuan ($2.6 billion) in the first nine months of 2024.

Sweet, milky and colourful, bubble tea is wildly popular in China, where people sipping through straws from large plastic cups is a common sight in high streets and shopping malls across the country (Jade GAO/AFP via Getty Images)

Earlier this week, McDonald’s revealed the breakfast orders of various celebrities the day after the Oscars celebrations. The commercial started with the time stamp of 9:14 a.m. at a McDonald’s restaurant in Hollywood.

The clip showed a receipt machine churning out the orders, such as Colman Domingo’s Egg McMuffin meal — which comes with hash browns and a coffee — with strawberry jelly and ketchup on the side.

Actor Teyana Taylor, who attended the Vanity Fair Oscar Party on Sunday, scarfed down McDonald’s Hotcakes (pancakes) with egg and sausage, a McChicken Biscuit with cheese, and a side of strawberry jelly and butter.

Singer Rosalía, who also attended the after-party, ordered a McGriddles — a breakfast sandwich with bacon, egg, and cheese — with a mango-pineapple smoothie and a mayo packet.

In February, McDonald’s reported a fourth-quarter net income of $2.02 billion, or $2.80 per share, down from $2.04 billion, or $2.80 per share, a year earlier.

The fast food chain’s sales suffered after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention linked a fatal E. coli outbreak to its Quarter Pounder burgers.

4.title: Chargers McDonald, Splain earn first team All-G-MAC honors for 2024-25 season
4.snippet: As Hillsdale prepares to battle for a G-MAC Tournament title this season, two of the main reasons behind one of the best women's basketball seasons in...
4.content: As Hillsdale prepares to battle for a G-MAC Tournament title this season, two of the main reasons behind one of the best women's basketball seasons in recent memory earned well-deserved awards this afternoon.Senior guardsandeach received first-team All-Great Midwest Athletic Conference honors for the 2024-25 season, the conference office announced on Thursday. The pair are two of just 10 players across the 13-team league to receive the distinction.The award is McDonald's second all-conference honor after earning second-team All-G-MAC in 2023-24, and comes as a deserving reward for one of the finest all-around seasons in program history. McDonald led the 20-8 Chargers in points, rebounds, assists and steals and ranked seventh or better in the G-MAC in all four categories, including second among all league players in both assists and steals per game, while also finishing in the top 10 in the G-MAC in both field goal percentage and free throw percentage.McDonald was a leader throughout the season for the Chargers, scoring in double figures in 23 of Hillsdale's 28 games, including six efforts of 20 or more points, headlined by a monster 30 point, 10 rebound double-double in Hillsdale's regular-season ending 68-61 win at Malone on March 1 that clinched a runner-up finish in the G-MAC. That was one of four double-doubles the 5-foot-9 point guard had during the 2024-25 season, along with 10 games with five or more assists and 12 games with three or more steals.A transfer from the Air Force Academy who has played just two and a half seasons at Hillsdale, McDonald has scored 936 points, grabbed 446 rebounds, dished out 216 assists, and grabbed 124 steals in just 57 starts for the Chargers. She surpassed 1,000 points for her collegiate career including her 172 points as a freshman at Air Force during a Feb. 8 game at Kentucky Wesleyan.For Splain, meanwhile, this first-team recognition is a well-earned first all-conference honor that caps a tremendous four-year career at Hillsdale for the 5-foot-8 guard. The senior put up career highs across the board, finishing second on the team in scoring with 13.2 points per game while also averaging 4.3 rebounds, 2.3 assists and 1.3 steals. Long known as a feared shooter from range, Splain showcased all aspects of a well-rounded game as a senior, and played her best in the biggest moments of the season for the Chargers, including 16 fourth-quarter points to lead Hillsdale to a 68-57 rivalry win on the road over Findlay on Feb. 20.Splain came to Hillsdale as an overlooked walk-on recruit from Olentangy Liberty High School near Columbus, Ohio, but quickly proved to be far more than her pedigree as she built up a record-setting career for the Chargers. On January 30, against Cedarville at home, Splain became the 21player in Hillsdale College history to surpass 1,000 points for her career, and she currently ranks 15on the all-time list with 1,145 points.Just two weeks later, in a Feb. 15 contest against Northwood, she broke Hillsdale's career made 3-pointers record, and now has 248 entering this weekend, 11 ahead of second place at Hillsdale and third in G-MAC history. Her 66 made 3-pointers so far in 2024-25 rank seventh in Hillsdale history for a single season and give her three of the top 10 all-time marks in made 3-pointers in program history.McDonald and Splain will look to help Hillsdale reach the G-MAC Tournament title game for the first time since 2018 in a semifinal matchup at 7:30 p.m. Friday against Malone at Ashland University. A victory would see the Chargers playing in the championship game on Saturday at 3 p.m.

6.title: McDonald’s Rolls Out AI Technology to Tackle Employees' 'Stress'
6.snippet: The fast food giant is giving more than 40000 restaurants an AI “makeover,” McDonald's Chief Information Officer told 'Wall Street Journal'
6.content:
McDonald’s latest change doesn’t come with a side of fries.

The home of the Big Mac is updating 43,000 restaurants with AI technology to target “stress” that employees deal with, McDonald’s Chief Information Officer Brian Rice told The Wall Street Journal on Wednesday, March 5.

“Our restaurants, frankly, can be very stressful. We have customers at the counter, we have customers at our drive-through, couriers coming in for delivery, delivery at curbside. That’s a lot to deal with for our crew,” Rice said.

McDonald's Ice Cream Cones. Alamy Stock Photo

Rice explained that the technology setup, called edge computing, is meant to quickly send data “to the cloud” so franchisees can see how their restaurants are operating. That data can include predictions about when kitchen equipment like fryers or infamously faulty ice cream machines will break down. Edge computing can also be used for AI-powered communication for the drive-through.

According to Rice, McDonald’s is exploring using computer vision, the form of AI used for facial recognition by TSA in airports. This technology would be used in cameras to “determine whether orders are accurate before they’re handed to customers,” per WSJ.

McDonald’s is implementing these technology initiatives to grow the number of customers from 175 million to 250 million by 2027.

While the AI news might not satisfy anyone’s hunger, the chain restaurant launched a celebrity-driven breakfast campaign on Monday, March 3.

Just one day after the 97th Academy Awards, McDonald's dropped a new commercial that spotlights Oscar-nominated actors and other attendees' go-to breakfast items.

"There's only one meal Hollywood relies on," the commercial declares, as order receipts featuring meals for Michael B. Jordan (two egg and cheese McMuffins and two hash browns with strawberry jelly), Jackie Chan (Sausage Egg McGriddle, apple pie and black coffee), Kieran Culkin (one small Coke) and many others.

7.title: Turn McDonald's Filet-O-Fish Into A British-Inspired Pub Classic
7.snippet: For fans of the Filet-O-Fish who are looking to upgrade their favorite fast food seafood sandwich, there's one hack that's as simple as it is satisfying.
7.content:
The hack itself might be one of the simplest out there. You don't need unusual sides, or double sauces, or a secret menu item that's not all that secret, like at Shake Shack. Nope, just drive or walk up to a McDonald's and order the Filet-O-Fish (or a Double Filet-O-Fish) and a small fries. Though this is a fairly simple order, a content creator testing this trick did observe that a small fries is no bargain these days since fast food has gotten so expensive (ordering it as a combo meal might help).

All you really need to do is layer hot, crispy french fries on top of the fish patty, and you've got a salty, umami, potato-sweet approximation of fish and chips ... on a bun. It's even served in a paper wrapper like classic British fish and chips, and McDonald's uses pollock, one of several fish commonly served as fish and chips.

There are a couple of tweaks you can make if you want to get even closer to the taste of classic fish and chips, long a defining street food in Britain. First, ask for no cheese or tartar sauce (though honestly both work pretty well here, and the tartar sauce holds the fries in place). Second, bring a packet or bottle of malt vinegar or Original HP sauce (also known as brown sauce). Both are considered traditional condiments with fish and chips (note that the vinegar might drip). And that's it!

8.title: McDonald's Has Removed Their Playscapes And Replaced Them With Two Screens
8.snippet: At first, my reaction to this was absolute disgust...look at how they massacred my boy! I recalled being a kid playing on random McDonald's playscapes with...
8.content:
At first, my reaction to this was absolute disgust...look at how they massacred my boy! I recalled being a kid playing on random McDonald's playscapes with such joy. I took out my phone and recorded a video:

I even found a photo of my hometown McDonald's playscape in West Hartford, CT! A place that no longer exists, which pains me deeply. What they don't tell you about getting older is the little reminders along the way. Everyone is ready for the sports stars to be much younger than you and your high school friends having kids, but your hometown McDonald's closing? That fucks you up man. You start to hear the clock ticking.

Unfortunately, McDonald's taking down the playscapes makes sense. They were, most likely, insurance nightmares for the company. Parents through the years started to realize how disgusting it is to let the kids play inside of them, which then led to corporate slowly seeing the space taken up by the multi-colored playscape as an absolute waste. To have them replaced by screens is a dagger to the heart. I may be a nostalgia merchant bringing up what McDonald's playscapes, but I think most would agree that kids running around is better than them plopped in front of a screen.

My biggest takeaway from all of this is big screen has won. They have defeated us. Our society is helplessly addicted to screens and it starts at a young age. This is yet another sad example.

The world we grew up in doesn't exist anymore.

1.title: City of Glencoe announces plans for McDonald’s to build new restaurant on the city’s east side
1.snippet: By Andrew MeulenersGeneral ManagerCity Administrator Mark Larson announced at the City Council meeting Monday night that McDonald's has received approval to...
1.content:
By Andrew Meuleners

General Manager

City Administrator Mark Larson announced at the City Council meeting Monday night that McDonald’s has received approval to build a new location east of Kwik Trip on the city’s east end.

The project, which involves no city incentives, is expected to be completed by the end of the construction season.

Stormwater management and MS4 permit

City engineer Justin Black of Short Elliott Hendrickson (SEH) provided an overview of the city’s Municipal Separate Storm Sewer System (MS4) permit, which is designed to reduce sediment and chemical runoff into Buffalo Creek, an impaired waterway. The city’s Stormwater Pollution Prevention Plan (SWPPP) outlines best management practices to mitigate environmental harm, such as algae blooms and fish kills caused by excess nutrients and pollutants.

Black highlighted ongoing initiatives, including the city’s rain barrel program, catch basin adoption efforts, and public education campaigns to reduce salt usage and properly dispose of pet waste. Residents can access resources and handouts at City Center to learn more about reducing stormwater runoff.

HVAC system upgrades approved

The council unanimously approved a $11,140 bid from ARI Mechanical, in partnership with Foster Mechanical, to upgrade the controls for the Glencoe Police Department’s HVAC system. The project includes low-voltage reconnections and replaces outdated equipment to improve efficiency. A second bid from UHL of Maple Grove was significantly higher due to additional communication equipment requirements.

Easements and land

purchase for Hennepin Avenue project

The council also approved the purchase of a three-acre parcel from Glencoe Regional Health Services for $36,000 to construct a stormwater holding pond as part of the Hennepin Avenue reconstruction project. The pond, required under the MS4 permit, will manage stormwater runoff and improve water quality before discharging into Buffalo Creek.

Additionally, the council approved permanent and temporary construction easements along 18th Street and Hennepin Avenue to address right-of-way discrepancies and facilitate utility connections. The city will split the cost of the land purchase with McLeod County, and the project includes wetland mitigation for approximately 0.15 acres of impacted farmland.

Library board

appointments

The council appointed Evon Draeger and Paula Bulau to the Glencoe Library Board. Both appointees previously served on the Cemetery Commission and bring valuable experience to their new roles.

Nuvera contract

update

Assistant City Administrator Mark Lehman provided an update on the city’s contract with Nuvera for IT services. The three-year agreement includes a 30-day termination clause and will streamline the city’s technology infrastructure. Nuvera also reduced the cost of installing fiber optic internet at the baseball field, ensuring high-speed connectivity for high school games and the state tournament this summer.

Park siding project progress

Lehman reported significant progress on the Vera Park siding project, with contractors completing much of the work despite windy conditions. The project, which includes upgrades to the park shed and restrooms, is expected to be finished within the next two weeks.

2.title: Jennifer Crumbley wants prosecutor removed from her case: 'She cannot be trusted'
2.snippet: Jennifer Crumbley doesn't just want a new trial, she's now seeking to have Oakland County Prosecutor Karen McDonald and her office removed from her case,...
2.content:
Jennifer Crumbley wants prosecutor removed from her case: 'She cannot be trusted'

Show Caption Hide Caption Oakland County Prosecutor speaks after James Crumbley found guilty Oakland County Prosecutor Karen McDonald spoke to the media after James Crumbley was found guilty on four counts of involuntary manslaughter

Jennifer Crumbley doesn't just want a new trial, she's now seeking to have Oakland County Prosecutor Karen McDonald and her office removed from her case, alleging McDonald has crossed multiple ethical and legal lines in handling her historic prosecution.

As part of this request, Crumbley's new lawyer disclosed new information Wednesday about the prosecutor's office: It paid nearly $36,000 to a public relations firm for one week of work after the Nov. 30, 2021, Oxford High School shooting — including setting up 40 one-on-one interviews with national media outlets — and is still paying a second PR firm $1,440 a month to monitor the news media, according to invoices listed in a Wednesday court filing.

Appellate attorney Michael Dezsi alleges these PR firms, including social media influencers, were used to run a "smear campaign" against Jennifer and James Crumbley, the first parents in America to be held responsible for a mass school shooting committed by their child.

More: Like his wife, James Crumbley asks for new trial: Prosecution kept evidence from me, too

"The Oakland County Prosecutor has demonstrated that she cannot be trusted to prosecute this case consistent with the constitutional, legal, and ethical duties imposed upon her office," Dezsi, argues in the new filing. "Since the inception of this case, the prosecutor has violated the court rules, entered into secret agreements with two star prosecution witnesses, and has unethically engaged two public relations firms to run a smear campaign against the Crumbleys in an effort to sway public opinion and taint the jury pool."

"For these reasons," Dezsi continues, "the prosecutor, and her entire office, should be removed from any and all further proceedings in this case."

Prosecutor calls defense 'ludicrous' — 'I stand by the work we did'

In a statement late Wednesday, Oakland County Prosecutor Karen McDonald called the defense's request "not legally proper," and lambasted Crumbley's lawyer over his filing.

"It’s disrespectful to the victims, their families, and the people in the community," McDonald stated, adding the defense also disrespected the court system, jury and her prosecution team. "I stand by the work we did."

She continued:

“The suggestion of a smear campaign is ludicrous. The crisis communications firms fielded an overwhelming number of media inquiries, not drumming up coverage. And their work was not secret. They were hired with the approval of the County Executive and the Board of Commissioners, and they interacted with the media on a daily basis."

McDonald called Dezsi's motion "nothing more than a desperate attempt to divert attention from Jennifer Crumbley herself."

“Jennifer Crumbley was convicted by a jury, not the media. And she was convicted for what she did and didn’t do," McDonald stated, reiterating the themes from trial: that Crumbley "boasted" about buying her son a handgun and taking him to the shooting range, "while ignoring her son’s pleas for help and all the signs that he was struggling, and then leaving the gun where he could access it."

Perhaps most egregious, McDonald maintains, is that "Jennifer Crumbley told the jury that she wouldn’t have changed a thing. We didn’t need a smear campaign to convict Jennifer Crumbley. Her own actions and words were more than enough."

Steve St. Juliana, whose 14-year-old daughter Hana died in the shooting, also scoffed at Dezsi's claims, saying in a statement: "Stop trying to make [Jennifer Crumbley] the victim. My daughter is the one that was murdered because of her negligence.”

Oakland County Executive Dave Coulter also jumped to McDonald's defense, saying in another statement: “In the immediate aftermath of the shooting, my administration and the Board of Commissioners moved quickly to provide the Prosecutor with the appropriate support she and her office needed to keep the public informed and to prosecute the case — including $500,000 for communications, information technology, security and other related costs.”

New request comes as judge prepares to make crucial decision

Dezsi's filing comes as Oakland County Circuit Judge Cheryl Matthews prepares to issue a decision on whether to give Jennifer Crumbley a new trial on alleged prosecutorial misconduct grounds.

At issue is whether the prosecution unlawfully withheld from the defense proffer agreements that it reached with two key school witnesses who were promised early on that their statements to investigators would not be used against them, and who later testified against Crumbley at her trial.

The agreements were first disclosed by the Free Press last March, after both Crumbleys were convicted in separate trials.

Dezsi has argued that those agreements should have been provided to Crumbley's legal team before trial, which would have allowed the defense to argue to jurors that the school witnesses were under the threat of prosecution themselves, and therefore not credible. Under the agreements, the witnesses were offered some assurances that they would not be prosecuted over statements they provided investigators, but the jury never got to hear that, Dezsi said.

The prosecution has argued that it was under no obligation to provide the proffer agreements to the defense because, it maintains, no immunity was provided. The prosecution also urged the judge to deny Crumbley's request for a new trial, arguing she was convicted fairly over her own actions and inactions that, prosecutors stress, cost four students their lives.

"She was the cause of these four deaths ... nobody else judge, her," Assistant Prosecutor Marc Keast has argued in court, referring to the four students who were killed in the Oxford shooting: Hana St. Juliana, 14; Madisyn Baldwin, 17; Tate Myre, 16, and Justin Shilling, 17. Six other students and a teacher also were injured.

The prosecution also has defended its use of the two PR firms hired after the shooting, maintaining it needed help handling the media in a case of this magnitude, noting it did not have a PR person on staff to handle such matters.

Shooting victim's parent: I can't go through this again

Craig Shilling, whose son Justin was killed in the Oxford High School massacre, struggles with the news that the Crumbleys are asking for a new trial.

"It's kind of a slap in the face," Shilling said. "I still stand strong with the fact that they could have done something more. Regardless of how they perceive the trial went. ... Overall, I feel that justice was served. ... I just feel that they dropped the ball 100% as far as their child was concerned, and I don’t think they did everything they could to protect the community."

Regarding the Crumbley's son, who committed the shootings, Shilling said: "He could have snapped on anybody."

Despite his pain and loss, however, Shilling said he understands that the justice system needs to be fair, and that he has "strong and mixed emotions" about the trial.

"I'm not necessarily 100% clear on the trial," Shilling said, noting he still is frustrated and upset that no school officials were ever charged or held responsible. But if the judge determines the Crumbleys didn't get a fair trial and orders new ones, he said that he understands.

"It has to be fair, and it has to be by (the) law," Shilling said of the Crumbley prosecutions. "It sucks to say that in the position that I’m in, but I don’t want anybody to break a law to have it happen."

He continued: "I have my firm belief in what should happen. ... I have to be fair. I try and keep an open mind on stuff, even hard stuff."

Still, he stressed: "I personally wouldn’t want to go through it again, it was hard enough the first time."

Defense: Prosecution spent $150,000 to two PR firms, at taxpayer expense

According to court records and public documents obtained by the Free Press, the prosecutor's office spent more than $150,000 on two PR firms since the school shooting.

The first was a national crisis response firm called Identity, which states on its website that it was hired by the prosecutor's office "in the hours following" the tragedy to "manage the media," and that it mobilized a "team of media and social media strategists who would spend the next eight days providing counsel" and responding to media requests worldwide.

These eight days of work cost taxpayers $35,839.25, according to documents obtained through the Freedom of Information Act. This is what Identity billed to manage more than 75 news media interviews for the prosecutor's office in one week, including 40 one-on-one interviews with national media outlets: Identity's hourly rate for its services ranged from $175 an hour to $300 an hour, the latter of which was paid to the company's president and managing partner, who together received $9,000 for 49 hours of work.

The second PR firm hired after the shooting was Moment Strategies, which is owned by former Detroit journalist Alexis Wiley, who, to date, has made about $120,000 doing PR work for the prosecutor's office. Wiley's latest $1,440 invoice for "daily media monitoring" went out on Feb. 1, with a March 3 due date.

"That is the last one," Wiley told the Free Press on Monday, noting that the prosecutor's office hired a full-time spokesperson in early January, so her services will no longer be needed.

According to Wiley, "daily media monitoring" involves notifying the prosecutor's office of any media reports — including newspaper and TV — that mention any criminal cases being handled by the prosecutor's office. She also defended her work, maintaining that in the wake of the shooting, the prosecutor's office had no PR person on staff who could handle the monumental case. She also has denied allegations that she was part of any "smear campaign," as alleged by the defense.

"The prosecutor's office had no communication support," Wiley said. "We provided that support at a fraction of the cost that it would be to hire someone in-house full-time. We did our work with integrity."

Defense: Prosecutor turned her office 'into makeshift Hollywood film set'

Dezsi, meanwhile, also takes issue with a Hulu documentary that aired about the Crumbleys nine days after James Crumbley was convicted. The executive producer of this documentary had family ties to Chief Assistant Prosecutor David Williams — she was his wife's cousin — and had inside access to the prosecutor's office for two years as it built its historic case against the Crumbleys.

More: Judge raises concerns about prosecutor's handling of Jennifer Crumbley case

"The Prosecutor also turned her office into a make-shift Hollywood film set," Dezsi argues in his court filing, referring to the ABC news crew that filmed the documentary, and was allowed into "closed-door strategy meetings."

Dezsi also takes issue with the prosecutor's office granting behind-the-scenes access to a Washington Post reporter "for the purpose of documenting the progress of the prosecutions related to the Oxford High School shooting.”

Defense: Here's how prosecution violated Michigan Rules of Professional Conduct

At a news conference Wednesday, Dezsi zeroed in on the Michigan Rules of Professional Conduct — which has a special section titled “Responsibilities of a Prosecutor” — alleging the Oakland County Prosecutor’s Office violated these ethical codes of conduct in two ways:

First, by withholding from the defense the proffer agreements that it brokered with two key school witnesses who testified against the Crumbleys. That’s a violation, Dezsi alleged, of Section 3.8 of the Rules of Professional Conduct, which says a prosecutor has a duty to “make timely disclosure to the defense of all evidence or information known to the prosecutor” that may be favorable to the defense.

“They have just outright lied about their obligation and duty to produce those proffer agreements to the defense,” Dezsi said, stressing that had the jurors known about those agreements, “they certainly could have reached a different outcome in the case.”

The second prosecutorial violation of the state’s rules, Dezsi said, involved the prosecutor using taxpayer funds to hire two public relations firms that he alleges engaged in a “smear campaign” against the Crumbleys and tainted the jury pool. One of those firms, Identity, received nearly $36,000 for one week’s worth of work alone — an amount that was approved by Chief Assistant Prosecutor David Williams, according to invoices filed in court.

“Why is that important?” Dezsi said. “Because the prosecutor's office has publicly said a few things that are false.”

Specifically, Dezsi said, the prosecution has maintained that Oakland County approved these PR contracts, but he alleged “that’s not what happened.”

Defense: Prosecutor asked for $1 million to prosecute the Crumbleys

“The Oakland County prosecutor asked for a million dollars from Oakland County to prosecute (the Crumbley) cases. A million dollars. Think about that. A million dollars put into a case to prosecute a couple from the community with very little resources. They didn't stand a chance. This is how they created an unequal playing field. They did it by use of these public relations firms that serve the purpose of spinning the narrative in favor of what the prosecutors wanted to have heard by the public.”

Dezsi alleges that not only is the use of PR firms by prosecutors “out of the ordinary or abnormal. It is unethical.” He said the Rules of Professional Conduct prohibit lawyers from using outside agents or public relations firms to do or say things that they themselves could not do or say — such as statements about the character or reputation of a party in the case that could prejudice them.

“And this is where you can look at it in a finer light to see what exactly the prosecutor did to publish and push a negative narrative about the Crumbleys,” Dezsi said.

To bolster his argument, Dezsi said he wants access to six reports that a PR firm called Identity put together in which it summarized all the press coverage and digital discussions. Dezsi said he has asked the judge to give him subpoena power that would help him get the reports.

“I intend to get them,” Dezsi said. “Because what I believe we're going to find is that these PR firms were telling the prosecutor's office what points were the most negative, what points were being repeated the most often in … the social media sphere, so that they could then focus and refocus their narrative and their talking points about the Crumbleys leading up til the trial.”

Jennifer Crumbley, along with her husband, James Crumbley, were convicted at separate jury trials of involuntary manslaughter for the deaths of four students killed by their son in the rampage at Oxford High School. The jury concluded the parents gave their minor son access to a gun and failed to secure it properly, which allowed him to sneak it out of the house and kill his classmates.

The shooter, who was 15 at the time, pleaded guilty to all of his crimes and is serving a life-without-parole sentence.

All three Crumbleys are appealing.

At a hearing related to Jennifer Crumbley's appeal in January, Judge Matthews expressed concern with the prosecution's actions involving the proffer agreements, saying: "Didn't the prosecution tack too close to the wind?" She also stressed that her job at hand was to determine whether the courts and public now lack confidence in the verdict — not whether the outcome would have been different had Crumbley had access to these proffer agreements.

(Editor's note: This story was updated with additional comments)

Contact Tresa Baldas: tbaldas@freepress.com

3.title: New McDonald's Happy Meal features Carmelo Anthony, Sabrina Ionescu more basketball stars
3.snippet: There's a new menu item at McDonald's perfect for ballers and basketball fans. Starting March 11, for the first time ever, the McDonald's All American Games...
3.content:
Check out the players featured on the packaging, as well as the prizes inside.

There's a new menu item at McDonald's perfect for ballers and basketball fans.

Starting March 11, for the first time ever, the McDonald's All American Games are coming to Happy Meals, the Golden Arches announced Wednesday.

McDAAG alums including Carmelo Anthony, Angel Reese, Sabrina Ionescu and Aaron Gordon will be featured on the star-studded kids meals, which will celebrate McDonald's historic legacy with basketball and the sport's next generation of greats.

McDonald's launched an All American Game themed Happy Meal. McDonald's

Each player is sporting the 2025 McDAAG jersey on the new Happy Meal box.

The Happy Meal comes with six different basketball hoop toys, with mini-basketball and trick-shot launcher, stickers and custom packaging for apple slices and milk.

Plus, a QR code on the box unlocks an integrated digital pop-a-shot gaming experience.

The new McDAAG Happy Meal is available while supplies last.

The 2025 McDonald's All American Boys Game will take place Tuesday, April 1, 2025 at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, New York. The Girls Game will be played immediately before the Boys Game.

4.title: Why Putin Can’t Wait to Have McDonald’s Back in Moscow
4.snippet: As the Trump administration pushes for renewed business ties with Russia, a new book looks back at the companies that helped prop up illiberalism in the...
4.content:
ZERO SUM: The Arc of International Business in Russia, by Charles Hecker

Perhaps nothing better captures the optimism that accompanied the last days of the Soviet Union than the opening of a McDonald’s in Moscow, in January of 1990. Tens of thousands of Russians applied to work at the restaurant, and tens of thousands more stood in line for hours to get their first taste of a Big Mac. On an adjacent building, the company had affixed its golden arches, above a much smaller display of the moribund empire’s red hammer-and-sickle flag. As a 4-year-old, I was among the many Muscovite children whose first encounter with American culture transpired over a Happy Meal.

And yet nothing gold can stay. The restaurant is still serving fries and shakes on Pushkin Square, but, as of mid-2022, it is under local ownership and rebranded as Vkusno i Tochka — Russian for “Tasty, Period.”

Not every Western company left the country after the Russian president Vladimir Putin launched a full-scale invasion of Ukraine, but sanctions, and the reputational cost of remaining, triggered an exodus. In “Zero Sum,” Charles Hecker chronicles this period, from the frenzied first moments of corporate investment in the midst of Soviet collapse to the run on business-class tickets that attended the scramble out of Moscow as Putin pressed in on Kyiv.

“Zero Sum” is a smart, often colorful book, enlivened by the grim smirk of someone who has intimate knowledge of how the everyday Russian economy really works. Hecker witnessed most of the three-decade saga up close, as a reporter for The Moscow Times and then as a geopolitical risk consultant advising Americans and Europeans investing in Russia. He arrived from Miami in the mid-90s, on the heels of what Harvard Business Review lauded as “a liberal-market revolution.”

5.title: How Dawn Staley responded to complaints South Carolina's 10 McDonald's All-Americans are too many
5.snippet: Dawn Staley was asked about recent comments that acknowledged how many McDonald's All Americans South Carolina has on its roster.
5.content:
How Dawn Staley responded to complaints South Carolina's 10 McDonald's All-Americans are too many

After South Carolina women's basketball beat Kentucky on Sunday, Wildcats coach Kenny Brooks made a reference in his postgame interview about how many McDonald's All-Americans are on coach Dawn Staley's roster.

"They were bringing in McDonald's All-Americans, four McDonald's All-Americans and just seeing which one was going to play better and they were fresh," said Brooks, whose Kentucky team has one compared to 10 for South Carolina.

Staley was asked Wednesday how she handles comments about South Carolina recruiting.

"Sometimes I have fun with it," Staley said. "Sometimes it's just, I would imagine that no one's turning down McDonald's All-Americans. I would imagine. We're just fortunate. And just so you know, just because you got a McDonald's All-American doesn't mean you got a great player.

"For us, we've attracted them because of the style of play, the style of discipline, the winning tradition, the growth, the producing pros. That's what attracts McDonald's All-Americans to us. And not even just that, we create meaningful relationships with the household. Not just the recruit, the entire household. So if the household's happy we've done our job. There's a lot of Happy Meals to go around."

On Monday, Staley posted a video on X, formerly known as Twitter, of her singing the McDonald's jingle.

"Ba Da Ba Ba Bah, I'm Lovin' It!," she said then smiled, with the caption saying "Hey Mickie you so fine you so fine you blow my mind ... hey Mickie!"

This was the second time an opposing coach addressed Staley's All-American-filled roster, the first was Kim Mulkey after the Gamecocks (27-3) beat LSU on Jan. 24.

"Got 10 All-Americans on a roster," Mulkey said before gasping while falling slightly back into her seat. "How do you even keep 10 on a roster."

South Carolina has 10 All-Americans on its roster and both of its 2025 recruits, Ayla McDowell and Agot Makeer, were named 2025 McDonald's All-Americans.

Makeer is the 21st McDonald’s All-American to sign with Staley out of high school and will be the 27th to play for Staley at South Carolina.

The Gamecocks may face either LSU or Kentucky in the 2025 SEC Tournament. Their first game is Friday at noon ET (ESPN) against the winner of Vanderbilt and Tennessee.

AWARD SEASON: South Carolina guard MiLaysia Fulwiley named 2025 SEC Sixth Woman of the Year

6.title: Maine mother told son 'a god' told her to kill him, court documents show
6.snippet: There are new and disturbing details on the death of a 14-year-old boy in central Maine.
6.content:
Warning: Some of the details in this article may be disturbing.

SIDNEY, Maine (WGME) -- There are new and disturbing details on the death of a 14-year-old boy in central Maine.

According to court documents, the boy's mother killed her son, saying she believed a god told her to.

Also read:

Police charged 39-year-old Megan McDonald with murder for the death of her son, 14-year-old Quincy McDonald, at their home in Sidney in December 2024.

According to an affidavit obtained by CBS13, police say McDonald told her son that "a god" chose her to carry out a murder-suicide and she had to sacrifice him.

Police say the teen tried to run from her, but she choked him with a scarf and then stabbed him in the chest.

Police say they found Quincy’s body in the backyard by a decorated Christmas tree on a blanket with his feet on a bible.

Police also say McDonald killed pets, including two tortoises, a gecko and a dog.

Also read:

According to the affidavit, she was going to then cut off her own head with a chainsaw but turned herself into police instead.

Investigators say McDonald told them she hadn't taken her meds since the previous April.

She's being held without bail and was ordered to undergo a psychiatric evaluation.

7.title: Helen Nugent Obituary March 5, 2025
7.snippet: Helen Nugent, 98, of Lynnfield died peacefully Wednesday, March 5, surrounded by her family.Born in Boston on July 19, 1926, she was the daughter of Michael...
7.content:
Helen Nugent, 98, of Lynnfield died peacefully Wednesday, March 5, surrounded by her family.

Born in Boston on July 19, 1926, she was the daughter of Michael and Catherine Harrington of Glengarriff, County Cork, Ireland.

Helen grew up in Arlington and was a longtime resident of Lynnfield. She loved spending time with her family and friends, attending her grandchildren’s sporting events, spending summers in Hampton Beach, and bowling into her 90’s, but her favorite hobby was shopping. She enjoyed traveling well into her 80’s and toured extensively through North America and Europe and sailed on several trans-Atlantic and Caribbean cruises. She was a voracious reader and became quite adept at searching the internet for news and current events as well as keeping in touch with friends and family through email.

Married for fifty-one years to the love of her life, Leo (d. 2001), Helen was the loving mother of four children: James Nugent of Boston, Patricia Hulse and husband Alyn of Herndon, VA, Thomas Nugent, MD of Winchester, KY, and Lianne Higgins and husband Robert of Hampton, NH. She was predeceased by her siblings, Mary Rudder, John Harrington, Catherine Hallinan, and Rev. James Harrington. She is survived by her sister Ann Kelley of Ft. Meyers, FL.

She was “Nana” to 10 grandchildren and 3 great grandchildren: Matthew (Sarah), Michael (Annie), Rosalyn, Halle (Justin), Shelby, Renzo, Trevor, Daniel (Amanda), Timothy (Julie), Kevin (Anastasia) and great-grandchildren: Mackenzie, Harrison and Ellie. She was also “Aunt” to many nieces and nephews.

Visitation for relatives and friends will be held at the McDonald Funeral Home, 19 Yale Ave., Wakefield on Thursday, March 13, from 5:00 – 7:00 p.m. Her Funeral Mass will be celebrated at Our Lady of the Assumption Church, 758 Salem St., Lynnfield on Friday, March 14, at 12:30 p.m. Burial will be private.

0.title: Anne (Bitsy) McDonald Cooper Obituary March 4, 2025 - McLane Funeral & Cremation Services
0.snippet: Anne (Bitsy) McDonald Cooper of Valdosta passed away Tuesday March 4, 2025 after a lengthy illness.Anne was born to the late Ernest J. and Virginia McDonald...
0.content:
Anne (Bitsy) McDonald Cooper of Valdosta passed away Tuesday March 4, 2025 after a lengthy illness.

Anne was born to the late Ernest J. and Virginia McDonald on May 19, 1943. Ernest and Virginia had McDonald’s nursery on Alden Ave where she learned about all variegations of Camellias and Azaleas. Anne attended Valdosta High School and graduated in the Class of 1961. She then attended Valdosta State College, Auburn University and transferred to the University of Georgia where she graduated with her Masters of Speech and Language Pathology. She was employed with the Lowndes County Board of Education where she provided speech therapy to many wonderful students, inspiring some to eagerly follow in her profession. She retired in 2000 and lived life! Anne was the most wonderful mother to her two boys, Jay and Alan Cooper. The three of them would have so many wonderful trips to Auburn, AL and St. George Island, FL where they made lifelong memories together. Anne and Alan would often visit small herb farms purchasing plants to bring home to raise. They frequented Mt Zion Music Hall to watch their favorites Bud Zorn and Don Mason perform. We know that she and Alan are dancing in heaven together now. Anne grew up in the Lee Street Baptist church and was a current member of First Methodist church in Valdosta.

Anne is survived by her son Jay Cooper and his wife Bridgette, brother Ernest M. McDonald and his wife Marjorie. Also many, many wonderful nieces and nephews, cousins and close friends. Anne was preceded in death by her loving son Robert “Alan” Cooper, her brother Fred McDonald, sister Mary Virginia and her husband Claude Moore of Auburn, AL.

Services will be held at 11am on Monday March 10, 2025 in the chapel of the Carson McLane Funeral Home of Valdosta. Family will receive friends prior to the service at 10-11am. Online condolences to the family may be shared at www.mclanecares.com.

Carson McLane Funeral Home

To order memorial trees or send flowers to the family in memory of Anne (Bitsy) McDonald Cooper, please visit our flower store

1.title: Struggle inside Maryland McDonald’s ends in murder charges for security guard
1.snippet: A security guard is facing murder charges after a struggle inside a McDonald's near the University of Maryland ended with a fatal gunshot inside the...
1.content:
A security guard is facing murder charges after a struggle Saturday night inside a McDonald's near the University of Maryland, College Park, ended with the guard firing a fatal gunshot inside the restaurant.

A security guard is facing murder charges after a struggle Saturday night inside a McDonald’s near the University of Maryland, College Park, ended with the guard firing a fatal gunshot inside the restaurant.

Murwanashyaka Francois, 54, was charged with second-degree murder in the death of 45-year-old Ricardo Clemons Jr.

According to charging documents, a witness told police Clemons frequently loitered at the McDonald’s at 2306 University Blvd. in Hyattsville, and was often asked to leave. Workers at the restaurant said they’ve called police in the past over Clemons’ behavior, documents stated.

Saturday, charging documents said Clemons refused to leave the McDonald’s and threatened to expose himself to an employee who asked him to leave the restaurant. The worker then asked Francois, a security guard at the McDonald’s, for help.

Footage from the restaurant shows Francois told Clemons to leave, then deployed pepper spray in Clemons’ face while Clemons was sitting at a table. According to video footage, Francois drew his baton after Clemons turned toward him. Clemons then lied on the floor.

As Francois was seen using his phone, Clemons got up and approached Francois, who exited the restaurant. Clemons returned to his booth, according to footage cited in court documents.

Francois reentered the McDonald’s and started giving Clemons commands, the documents stated, adding once Clemons tried to stand up, Francois pushed him down with his baton multiple times.

Clemons then grabbed Francois’ baton and a struggle ensued, during which Francois pulled his gun. Francois regained control of the baton and holstered his firearm.

Clemons turned his back to Francois, who then struck Clemons in the back with his baton, sparking another struggle, during which the two men exchanged blows, according to charging documents.

Francois dropped his baton after being punched in the head during the fight, then pulled his gun and fired a shot toward Clemons, striking him in the chest, the documents stated.

Police said Clemons was not armed and that Francois is an armed security guard for Strategic Security Corp., who has a permit to carry a firearm.

Prince George’s County police said Francois’ actions initiated the entire physical encounter, and said witness statements and footage also justified the murder charge.

Francois was ordered held without bond Monday and is scheduled for a preliminary hearing April 1.
